bestBHT.bht: The scribes depicted here were ruthless in their exploitation of widows, taking advantage of their vulnerable state to seize their belongings while appearing righteous with their long prayers. Their actions will lead to greater damnation, evoking a parallel to the condemnation seen in Matthew 23:14. The description of these scribes as voracious, cruel, and hypocritical emphasizes the severity of their wrongdoing, particularly in using religion as a cover for their wicked deeds.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: devour, &c.—taking advantage of their helpless condition and confiding character, to obtain possession of their property, while by their "long prayers" they made them believe they were raised far above "filthy lucre."
So much 'the greater damnation' awaits them.
What a lifelike description of the Romish clergy, the true successors of 'the scribes!'
John Gill: They were very voracious and cruel; they did not spare widows, but devoured their substance.
Doing such wickedness under a cloak of religion will aggravate their condemnation.

bhtAttempts.bht: The scribes in Luke 20:47 are described as devouring the property of helpless widows, all the while appearing devout and pious through their long prayers. These scribes, who are compared to the Romish clergy, took advantage of the widows' vulnerability and conned them out of their belongings. Such deceitful actions warrant a greater condemnation for these scribes. Their voracious and cruel behavior, coupled with their false religiosity, only adds fuel to their impending condemnation. This description echoes the sentiment expressed in Matthew 23:14.

The scribes in question, likened to the Romish clergy, seized the opportunity to exploit widows and take their property, all while pretending piety through lengthy prayers. Their actions will result in an even harsher judgment. Their cruelty and insincerity only worsen their condemnation, paralleling the condemnation described in Matthew 23:14.

These scribes, akin to the successors of the Romish clergy, cunningly devoured the possessions of widows, shamelessly hiding behind their supposed holiness. Their deceitful practices and abuse of vulnerable individuals will ultimately incur a severe damnation. This portrayal serves as a sobering reminder of the warning in Matthew 23:14, highlighting the dire consequences of using religion as a disguise for wickedness.

The scribes depicted here were ruthless in their exploitation of widows, taking advantage of their vulnerable state to seize their belongings while appearing righteous with their long prayers. Their actions will lead to greater damnation, evoking a parallel to the condemnation seen in Matthew 23:14. The description of these scribes as voracious, cruel, and hypocritical emphasizes the severity of their wrongdoing, particularly in using religion as a cover for their wicked deeds.

The scribes, compared to the Romish clergy, shamelessly devoured the property of widows, cunningly hiding their greed behind a facade of piety and religious devotion. Such deceitful practices will only lead to a more severe condemnation. Their voracious and cruel behavior, coupled with their false religiosity, aggravates their impending judgment. This echoes the warning found in Matthew 23:14, illustrating the dire consequences of disguising wickedness with religious appearances.
